text: - Over the past decade, we've stayed

in hundreds of unique rental
properties around the globe.
So we've partnered with Airbnb,

to create a series
called, "Meet Your Host."
Their platform has seen tremendous success
for hosts of unique stays.

We'll be visiting these unique
properties around the world

and hearing from the people
who brought them to life.
(upbeat music)

Welcome to another episode
of "Meet Your Host."

Today, I am in Ybor City,
which is a neighborhood

in Tampa, Florida, where I'm
meeting up with Stephanie.
Her and her husband, David have, not one,

but two tiny houses on
Airbnb, and they designed them

and built them themselves,
they got a little influence
from the shotgun shacks here in Ybor.

So I'm really excited to go
in and actually take a look.
Let's go.

Hi, Stephanie.

which I love, why tiny houses?

So it didn't really start as a house,

I think that when David

obviously you're living
in really tiny space,
and we realized how nice it was,

and kind of how freeing

It's nice to introduce like

It doesn't get too, too warm.

So Ybor was kind of came
up a couple centuries ago

as a place for cigar workers
to come from Spain, from Cuba,
from Latin America.
So all of the cigar workers lived
in these tiny little shotgun shacks.

So we mimicked those kind
of in a more modern way.
So that's how we got kind of like the form
and overall shape of these.

So a shotgun shack is a
tiny house that is lined up

and laid out so that if you
have the front door open

and the back door open, you
can literally shoot a shotgun

through it, and it will go
out from the front door,
out the back door.

So each room is behind
the room in front of it.

So it's just like a row
of rooms, if you will.

living in 300 square foot
apartments in New York

that you don't usually
learn living in Florida

because you don't have to
live in such a small space.
- I'd love to know too
about the more technical parts about this.

- Sure, so that's the
fun and nerdy part for me
as an architect.

So we built both of these
tiny houses using SIPs panels,
which are structural insulated panels.
So they're basically 26 gauge metal
with a styrofoam sandwich in between.

So it goes together kind of
modularly, it's almost prefab.

Everything comes together,
so floor, walls, roof,
all SIPs panels.

So you get them onsite,
you cut them to the length
that you need.

You bolt them all together and
you have the whole envelope,

ready to go in a couple of
days, which is really nice.

And it keeps things really
cool and pretty quiet.

Plumbing wise, the houses
are raised up off the ground,
so it's pretty simple.

Everything runs under the house
and up to where we need it.
So this is a historical district.

So we had to get like
historic committee approval
to build these, and people had a hard time

wrapping their heads around
building something so small,
they just, they couldn't get it.

They were like, "Well,
why don't you just build
a normal three bedroom house?"

And we're like, "No, like
we don't want to do that."
This is, this is the fun part.
- [Kristen] Yeah.

- Like let us do this thing
and now that they're built

people get it, but it was a
learning and teaching process
for everyone.
- [Kristen] How long did it take you
to build this first house?

- It took us probably
about six months to build,
because we were in New York.

We had a contractor friend who
was kind of doing most of it,

but we still wanted to be
here for large parts of it,

to kind of manage, and, we were
doing a lot of design build,

we hadn't figured out all of
the details ahead of time.

So we wanted to be here as
things were taking shape,

to make sure they looked
like what we wanted them

to look like, being architects,
we were pretty picky
about a lot of things.
We did not take the easy road by far.

So we had a lot of lessons
learned, but, it was fun.
And the cool thing about both of these is

that they are built in
such a way that we can

cut the foundation
systems off and move them
if we ever want to.
- Nice.

- So in that respect, it is
kind of like a little bit

of a traditional tiny house
and that they're movable-ish.
My husband and I being architects,

we knew that we wanted
to build these the way

that we wanted them at
which was definitely not

the cheapest or easiest way
to build any part of these.
So I think on a per square foot basis,

both of these were a little
over $200 a square foot,

which when people hear that
they kind of freak out,
but it costs more to build small,

because if you think about
it, if you have a plumber

or an electrician come
out, they're still plumbing
or wiring the same amount of fixtures.
So even though the square footage is less,

it's the same amount of
work for most of the trades,
but we would do it the same again.
And we will in the future, 'cause we just,

we think it looks right,
it looks appropriate
and that's fun, that's fun for us.
(upbeat music)

We initially put this
house on Airbnb just to see

if it could pay for itself,
and that was going to be,

all we needed, and we've
been pleasantly surprised

with the fact that it
does spit out some income
and that income we can turn around.
So we took the income from this house,

we turned it around and put
it toward the second house.

And so it's just kind of
like a moving, moving,

fluidity of money to like
funnel into other things.
So it's been good.
Because the first one was so successful,

that's why we decided to build
the second one so quickly.

We thought we would
take a little more time,
but we ended up not.

And I think the success that
we've had with these houses

has allowed us to continue to
do small development projects,
which is really what we love to do.

Living here while we
were building next door,
this is not a full kitchen,

so we installed those

We planted these a couple of years ago

to be taller than a house already.

It looks a little silly

to put the third house

we didn't want to have to

So we were trying to landscape knowing

Luckily, Ybor is super urban

So nowhere else in Florida

could you build something so small legally

Like people have like

So it's nice to just be able

My husband and I are both big travelers,

we traveled independently
before we met each other

and now we travel together,
but we just, we used Airbnb.

So it was kind of an easy
decision to go with them.

It was a platform that we
already knew as guests,
so it seemed very intuitive.

And thankfully we've learned
that it is pretty intuitive

for hosts, so it was
just an easy decision.
We didn't put a ton of thought into it.
Once we put this up on Airbnb,

we realized that there weren't
very many Airbnbs in Tampa

and especially in this
neighborhood at all at the time
in 2015, so our popularity (snaps)
kind of took off pretty quickly,

especially given the
novelty of the house itself.
When I first started hosting,
I had a full-time job in New York,

in the corporate world
and I had a lot going on.
And so I was a little nervous

about just the time
requirement needed for hosting,
but it's been super easy.

I've found that even for
introvert like myself,

I really, really love the
interactions with guests.
Like people, I love answering questions.

Our tagline for the house
is that "Every guest

can be a local," so we love
providing everyone with,

our personal recommendations
for the neighborhood.
My husband's born and raised here,
so he knows everything and everyone.
Ybor is a really unique neighborhood
because it is a historic district.
It's the entertainment district.
It's really close to downtown.
It's really close to the cruise port.

It's really close to
the convention center.
So we get such a wide variety of guests.
You have the 20 year olds who are coming
for a hip hop concert.

You have the 70 year olds
who are leaving on a cruise
and just want to come to Tampa
for a couple of days beforehand.
The demand is huge for, for both houses.

And sometimes people like
can't choose which one
they want to stay in.

So we have repeat guests
and they literally,

one time they'll stay in
one and then they'll come

to the other one and
they hop back and forth.

The favorite pieces of
feedback that we get is,
people are like, "I just want to go home."
And home for them means these houses,
they're out having fun in Ybor,
and they're like, "Let's go home."
